## Estimating Formulas

If the tabulated data are missing </br>
use a formula like Kopp's rule

$\hspace{3pt} (C_p)_{\text{compound}} = \sum\limits_{\text{all atoms}} C_{pa}$

$\hspace{1pt}$

How about mixtures?

$\hspace{1pt}$

Lacking other data, use a </br>
weighted average.

{image}

## 
 
The $C_p \Delta T$ changes are known as $\textit{sensible heat changes}$. During a
phase change, heat is added without a change in temperature.
Such changes are $\textit{latent heat changes}$.

 * Latent heat of vaporization, $\hspace{4pt} \Delta \hat{H}_v$
 * Latent heat of fusion, $\hspace{4pt} \Delta \hat{H}_m$
 * Latent heat of sublimination, $\hspace{4pt} \Delta \hat{H}_s$

$\hspace{1mm}$

Why $\Delta H$? Why not $\Delta U$?

## 

Vaporize one pound of water at constant $T$ and $P$. What kind of
system?

$\hspace{1mm}$

The $1$st law is: $\Delta U = Q + W$

$\hspace{1mm}$

For a closed system the pressure-volume work is:

<center> $W = -\int P dV$ </center>

$\hspace{1mm}$

Now if $P =$ constant

<center> $W = -P\Delta V = -\Delta (PV)$ </center>

$\hspace{1mm}$

So the $1$st law becomes:

<center> $\Delta U_v = Q - \Delta (PV)$ </center> 

##

or
<center> $\Delta U_v + \Delta (PV) = \Delta H_v = Q$ </center>

$\hspace{1mm}$

The book lies a little. It should say on page $265$, "If a phase change takes place in a $\textit{constant volume}$ closed system..."

$\hspace{1mm}$

<center> $\Delta \hat{U}_m \approx \Delta \hat{H}_m$ </center>

<center> $\Delta \hat{U}_v \approx \Delta \hat{H}_v - RT$ </center>

##

How do you evaluate latent heats?

 * Tables
 * Correlations
 * Educated Guesses

$\hspace{1mm}$

$\textbf{Trouton's Rule (within 30\% accuracy)}$ </br>
nonpolar liquids
<center> $(\Delta \hat{H}_v)_{nbp}$ [$\textrm{kJ/mol}$] $\approx 0.0088T_b (K)$ </center>

$\hspace{1mm}$

water, low-MW alcohols

<center> $(\Delta \hat{H}_v)_{nbp}$ [$\textrm{kJ/mol}$] $\approx 0.109T_b (K)$ </center>

## Chen's equation (within 2% accuracy)

$\hspace{1mm}$

<center> $(\Delta \hat{H}_v)_{nbp} = \dfrac{T_b[0.331(T_b/T_c) - 0.0327 + 0.0297\log_{10} P_c]}{1.07 - (T_b / T_c)}$ </center>

with $T$'s in Kelvin, $P$ in atm, and $\Delta H$ in $\textrm{kJ/mol}$

$\hspace{1mm}$

Also $\textbf{Clausius and Claperyon backwards}$

<center>$\ln p^* = -\dfrac{\Delta \hat{H}_v}{RT} + B$</center>

<center>$\dfrac{d(\ln p^*)}{d(1/T)} = -\dfrac{\Delta \hat{H}_v}{R}$</center>

##

And finally if you have $\Delta \hat{H}_v$ at one temperature and you need it at
another, the $\textbf{Watson correlation}$

<center> $\dfrac{\Delta \hat{H}_v (T_2)}{\Delta \hat{H}_v (T_1)} = (\dfrac{T_c - T_2}{T_c - T_1})$ </center>

$\hspace{1mm}$

$\textbf{Page 266's Rule (??\% accurate)}$ </br>
For metallic elements

<center>$\Delta \hat{H}_v (\textrm{kJ/mol}) \approx 0.0092 T_m (K)$</center>

For inorganic compounds
<center>$\Delta \hat{H}_v (\textrm{kJ/mol}) \approx 0.0025 T_m (K)$</center>

For organic compounds
<center>$\Delta \hat{H}_v (\textrm{kJ/mol}) \approx 0.050 T_m (K)$</center>
